guide.label: Local knowledge
guide.title: Lake Constance, in brief
guide.subtitle: Get on the water faster: the key patterns, decisions, and caveats in a calm overview.
guide.card1.title: Navigation vs. reality
guide.card1.text: It looks small but behaves like a real inland sea: local wind shifts, short waves, and busy traffic. Plan with margin and keep alternatives in mind.
guide.card2.title: Anchoring is not the default
guide.card2.text: Many areas are sensitive or restricted. A good spot is not just depth: think shelter, seabed, distance, and whether overnighting is practical and allowed.
guide.card3.title: Borders and jurisdictions
guide.card3.text: DE, CH, and AT meet on the lake. Rules, radio, marina regulations, and fees can differ. When it matters, verify via official sources.
guide.how.title: How to use this site
guide.how.p1: Start with the map for distances and alternatives. Then filter the lists by country and draft. Open any entry to see details, notes, and sources when available.
guide.how.p2: The goal is not completeness at all costs, but a calm and useful starting point. If something is missing or wrong, report it via GitHub.
faq.label: Answers
faq.title: FAQ
faq.subtitle: Short, honest answers to the questions that come up again and again.
faq.a1: No. There are protected areas, traffic lanes, and local rules. Use the list as a starting point and verify official notices on site.
faq.a2: No. Levels change and data can go stale. If it is critical, plan conservatively and verify with up-to-date charts and local information.
faq.a3: Where possible we include a source and a last-verified date. If missing, treat it as a hint, not a promise.
faq.a4: Yes. The fastest way is via GitHub: open the repo, file an issue, or propose a small fix. Sources and dates help a lot.
faq.disclaimer.title: Data and responsibility
faq.disclaimer.text: This site does not replace official charts, marina rules, or safety information. It is a curated overview for planning and inspiration. Responsibility stays with the skipper.
safety.label: Safety
safety.title: Weather, warning system, decisions
safety.subtitle: Most bad days on the lake are not about sailing skills, but timing. These basics help decision-making.
safety.card1.title: Strong wind warning
safety.card1.text: 40 orange flashes per minute: risk of gusts 25–33 kn. Adjust plan and course now.
safety.card2.title: Storm warning
safety.card2.text: 90 orange flashes per minute: risk of winds 34 kn and above. Seek shelter, reduce early, no debate.
safety.card3.title: Traffic and ferries
safety.card3.text: Around harbors, crossings, and shorelines traffic is busy. Plan defensively and expect others to change course.
safety.sources.title: Sources
safety.sources.text: The storm warning values (40 and 90 flashes per minute) are described officially. Links are in the sources section.
sources.label: Sources
sources.title: Further reading
sources.subtitle: Official and useful pages for rules, warnings, and current info. If it matters, verify here.
safety.checklists.title: Checklists
safety.checklists.before.title: Before you leave (2 minutes)
safety.checklists.before.i1: Checked storm warning lights (or an official source) and understood the weather situation.
safety.checklists.before.i2: Have Plan A and Plan B harbors in mind (including approach).
safety.checklists.before.i3: Reefing plan: when to reef, who does what.
safety.checklists.before.i4: Crew briefing: maneuvers, gust handling, who steers, who keeps lookout.
safety.checklists.before.i5: Engine check: start, cooling, enough fuel for return and maneuvers.
safety.checklists.strong.title: In a strong wind warning (40 flashes/min)
safety.checklists.strong.i1: Reduce sail early, before it becomes unpleasant.
safety.checklists.strong.i2: Increase distance to lee shores and narrow areas.
safety.checklists.strong.i3: Prioritize harbors and choose a course that makes aborting easy.
safety.checklists.storm.title: In a storm warning (90 flashes/min)
safety.checklists.storm.i1: Don’t do “just quickly across”: seek shelter early.
safety.checklists.storm.i2: Secure crew, assign clear roles, simplify maneuvers.
safety.checklists.storm.i3: If unsure: use engine, keep course stable, de-escalate the situation.
safety.checklists.anchor.title: If you want to anchor
safety.checklists.anchor.i1: Only in suitable conditions: shelter, depth, seabed, clearance, traffic.
safety.checklists.anchor.i2: Plan conservatively: more rode, more margin, abort earlier.
coverage.title: Data coverage
coverage.note: Verified means: a source and date are present. Unverified does not mean wrong, just not yet properly referenced.
